ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: So much audio programs, so much breakout rooms
In class discussions
We just met on Zoom every morning and used the break out room feature a lot.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It was a good review of all the French grammar tenses, but it moved through them really really fast.
Reading comprehension, intensive grammar, and conversational skills.
I learned and relearned a lot of French from my prior classes. I learned some new tenses and strengthened my skills in old tenses. I read French books for the first time and watched a French movie.

I learned about the french grammar taught in L1 and L2, practiced my oral production and auditory discrimination skills as well as read my first french novels! We also watched a french movie and were tested on reading comprehension and our ability to make connections and observe themes in the french media.
I became much more confident in speaking French and reinforced my grammar skills. I also improved my reading listening comprehension.
You really will learn how to speak french in this course. It's hard but so worth it!

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a large breadth of information however, I felt like this course was often lacking in depth of information and I wonder how much of the information I learned will stick as I move to more advanced French courses.

The discussion format worked really well and I feel like we really talked a lot in French. The materials we studied (books, movies, etc.) were interesting and helped illuminate different aspects of French we hadn't looked at before. In terms of weaknesses, it was just a lottt of work. It's clear signing up for it that you'll be in for a lot, but if it could just be taken down a peg or two, that would help out so much in terms of stress prevention, especially during COVID-19.

This course was taught very well and had a great structure to it with the course packet, novels, and film with clips. I would not change anything. I do wish that my grades were uploaded to Canvas so that I could know how my grades were adding up. I also wish that when receiving my exam grades, I could be told what questions I got wrong with right and wrong answers and copies of the audio clips to check them again.

This course, like many other language courses, seems to assume that students have no other classes or obligations that take precedence over it. The reality is that this course isn't too difficult, but burdens students with far too much homework in such a short time. Otherwise, it's a very enjoyable course and very instructive.

One strength of this course is that we got daily practice speaking in large and small group settings over Zoom. Additionally, the listening practice in class was very helpful and the reading materials were very interesting and helpful.
I wish there was a bit more time to practice speaking during class but that's obviously difficult because of the online format.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Zoom breakout rooms were great but I felt like I was missing direct guidance and feedback from my instructor. Also, being in person on zoom sometimes felt like overkill and I think some aspects of this course could have been asynchronous.

The discussion format of the class worked well and breakout rooms were used very well to help us dive further into texts. Canvas is really vital for online learning, though, and I really think the organization of materials on canvas could be improved. Some materials are on the umbrella site, some on the specific class site, and especially on the individual class site, there were very few folders, so if you didn't know exactly what the title was it was often very difficult to find specific files.
I enjoyed the break out rooms a lot. It would also be helpful if some time could be set aside for break out rooms to practice spontaneous conversation like talking about our weekend etc.
The breakout rooms worked really well!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would only recommend taking this class if you need it for your language requirement. The class plows through difficult material really fast, there is a lot of homework, and the grading is really harsh. That said, the books you read/movies you watch are good.
Yes- while this course was intense it gave me the push I needed to improve my French language skills.
I would. It was very difficult with a lot of work but I do think I learned a lot. The classroom environment really encouraged everyone to participate and it felt like a productive environment.

If you are want to learn more about the french language and speak it orally then this is the correct course for you. However, be aware of the time commitment needed to stay on track with daily assignments.

I would definitely recommend this course to another student! You feel much more capable of french after having read a few books and watched a movie in the language. Also, the grammar is all a review for the most part, so it is not too much new besides vocab and idiomatic phrases.
French is a good way to fulfill language requirements and if you're interested in learning it, I'd say to go for it. But choose a language you genuinely enjoy studying or want to speak.

I would recommend this course to other students wanting to improve their speaking skills and read French literature. I think all of the students in my class made great progress over the semester and the course was very conducive to improvement.
Yes. L3 is definitely hard but so worth it if you're trying to become fluent.
